# Introduction {background-image="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/results/neonet_kcc_7k.png"}

## HG and EF

<table style="font-size: 30px;">
  <tr>

  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td>Baume de Montclus<br><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-simep/img/moments-dbs-meso-Montclus.png-spd.png"></td>
    <td>
      <span style="color:#0000CF">EM Early Mesolithic</span> Continuation of the hunter-gatherer lifestyle. Pleistocene/Holocen transition. Late Last Glacial Maximum climate.<br>
      <span style="color:#1D1DFF">MM Middle Mesolithic</span> Increased specialization in tool production, territorialisation. New climates: new species.<br>
      <span style="color:#3737FF">LM Late Mesolithic</span> Residenciality increase. Circular mobility to access discontinuous resources in time and space
    </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td>Franchti cave<br><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-simep/img/moments-dbs-neo-Franchti.png-spd.png"></td>
    <td>
      <span style="color:#FF1B1B">EN Early Neolithic</span> Early farmers. Permanent settlements, soil fertility for  wheat and barley and climates: sheep, goats, pigs, and cattle. Warm and stable climate.<br>
      <span style="color:#FF8D1B">MN Middle Neolithic</span> Crafware, crops and livestock specialisation. Deforestation. Warm and stable climate.<br>
      <span style="color:#FFC04D">LN Late Neolithic</span> Apparition of copper industry. Marginal land brought into cultivation. More variable climate conditions
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>



::: notes
Periods are quoting moments. We use a conventional division in 3 phases, both for the Mesolithic and Neolithic, a standardized and heuristic way to represent the evolution of a culture. Here it represents, large brushes:
:::

### is.not.in Aberrant dates

[c14_aberrant_dates.tsv](https://github.com/zoometh/neonet/blob/main/inst/extdata/c14_aberrant_dates.tsv)

```{r, message=FALSE}
library(DT)
c14.to.remove = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/main/inst/extdata/c14_aberrant_dates.tsv"
df.to.rm <- read.table(c14.to.remove, sep = "\t", header = TRUE)
datatable(df.to.rm)

```


:::

::: notes
NeoNet is one of the numerous existing radiocarbon datasets. That's why we have developed a *getter* function within the C14bazaar package for the dataset's to be harvestable.
:::
